review.title: A study on the relation between linguistics-oriented and domain-specific semantics
review.abstract: In this paper we dealt with the comparison and linking between lexical resources with domain knowledge provided by ontologies. It is one of the issues for the combination of the Semantic Web Ontologies and Text Mining. We investigated the relations between the linguistics oriented and domain-specific semantics, by associating the GO biological process concepts to the FrameNet semantic frames. The result shows the gaps between the linguistics-oriented and domain-specific semantics on the classification of events and the grouping of target words. The result provides valuable information for the improvement of domain ontologies supporting for text mining systems. And also, it will result in benefits to language understanding technology.

It is one of the questions for combining Semantic Web Ontologies and Text Mining. We explored the relationships between linguistically oriented and domain-specific semantics by linking GO's biological process concepts with the semantic frames of FrameNet. The result shows the gaps between linguistically oriented and domain-specific semantics in classifying events and grouping target words. The result provides valuable information for improving domain ontologies that support text mining systems, and it will also bring benefits to language understanding technology.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: The combination of ontologies and text mining (TM) was considered important within the life science research community to track the knowledge contained in the increasing accumulation of scientific literature available online (e.g. [5]). Although most of them were not developed for natural language analysis, ontological resources provide the domain knowledge required by text mineral systems. In addition, they provide the framework for consistent semantic integration of the various resources used in a text mineral system, as well as the integration of knowledge from other resources such as databases. This is in line with the vision of the semantic web that we use to combine the two technologies.

sections.heading: 2 Method
sections.text: To collect the semantic frames (Releases 1.3), which are largely valuable for the description and processing of text in molecular biology, we have used biomedical verbs available through the PASBio project (Releases 1.0). It represents 29 verbs (representing 34 predicates) that have been selected for their use in the description of gene expression and related events. Assigning an FN frame to a verb is based on the definition of PAS predicates and their arguments, FN frames has become a candidate framework for a verb if the verb is a LU in the FN frame. We discard FN frames that either have completely different meanings for the verb or are too specific for biological situations. If there was no entry for the verb or gives all available frames for a verb, synonyms or words in its definition are discarded.
